texts.shortText: Forms large, tough, dark-red, oval blades emerging from a narrow stem and attached to a small, disc-like holdfast. Gametophyte phase has a few surface papillae and numerous small ones around perimeter of blade. Tetrasporophyte (depicted in photograph) has a smooth surface and marginal papillae, but its most characteristic feature is that when spores are released the blade disintegrates to becomes a lacy mass of holes.
Blades up to about 500 mm tall, but more typically 250 mm.

Global: Southern African endemic.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape of Good Hope.

Very distinctive and common species found on intertidal rocks in the mid- to low shore. As with other species in this group has potential as a source for the extraction of carrageenan, a chemical used in the food industry as a gelling and thickening agent.
Tetrasporangial sori disintegrate after producing spores, leaving holes in the blades.
The holes on the fronds of mature tetrasporophyte easily distinguish this from several other local Gigartina species.
